image.altText: black and white graphic showing old newspaper articles saying slacks banned

props.synopsis: When Dorothy Henderson-Smart based her decision to wear trousers on convenience, little did she know she'd end up making headlines. Years later, her family has uncovered the story of the "girl who shocked Canberra".

title.children: 'The girl who shocked Canberra': Dorothy Henderson-Smart and the fashion choice that sparked a national outcry

image.altText: The ACT Supreme Court towards dusk.

props.synopsis: The 27-year-old man has been jailed for a dramatic attack and robbery with two others, after the victim recognised him because they'd been to school together.

title.children: Canberra man jailed for over two years for 'cowardly' unprovoked robbery

image.altText: Three men stand with their arms around one another, all smiling.

props.synopsis: Victor Croker and Dave Leemhuis struggled to keep their bees alive during winter so they developed a new insulated hive. It's proved so popular among beekeepers that 500 are now being shipped to the United States each week.

title.children: These beekeepers created a new type of hive that's so popular they're shipping 500 to the US each week

image.altText: A man sings passionately into a with a drummer behind him playing.

props.synopsis: Changes to noise restrictions which will allow sounds of up to 75 decibels until 1am over the weekend in the city have been wholeheartedly embraced by the live music sector in Canberra.

title.children: 'Fun is not silent': Live entertainment noise limits in city relaxed significantly

image.altText: A sitting dog looks up at the camera.

props.synopsis: Oakley, the six-year-old border collie, is a conservation detection dog who sniffs out noxious alligator weed in Canberra's Lake Burley Griffin.

title.children: Conservation detection dog Oakley having a ball patrolling Lake Burley Griffin for invasive weed

image.altText: A prototype of a lunar rover, with big black wheels, a gold body and a panel on the side.

props.synopsis: An Australian-made rover called Roo-ver will be part of an upcoming NASA mission to the Moon to help extract oxygen and metals from lunar soil.

title.children: Could this prototype become Australia's first Moon rover?

image.altText: a young man smiling and holding a guitar

props.synopsis: Jetson's parents believe his death was one of the first overdoses to involve nitazene, which is increasingly being found in illicit drugs and counterfeit pharmaceuticals.

title.children: 'He didn't know the risks': Fake pharmaceuticals laced with a deadly synthetic opioid claim young man's life

image.altText: A man giving a speech with an animated expression and his hand extended to the side

props.synopsis: Donald Trump suggests Kamala Harris approaches economic policy in "a communist way" and calls her a "lunatic" ahead of the Democratic National Convention.

title.children: Harris campaign hits back at Trump's 'lies, name-calling, and confused rants' ahead of DNC

image.altText: Three men in orange ski wear pull a red flag off a large plaque on a sunny icy tundra

props.synopsis: It might look like an ice-bound resort but China's latest Antarctic station, Qinling, has Australia's intelligence community concerned.

title.children: China's new Antarctic base looks like a luxury, ice-bound resort, but it has Western spies worried

image.altText: Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant

props.synopsis: The International Atomic Energy Agency warns safety at Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant in south-eastern Ukraine is deteriorating, after a recent drone strike outside its protection zone.

title.children: Nuclear danger heightens amid military attacks on Europe's largest power facility, IAEA warns

image.altText: the mayor of woollahra council in sydney richard shields stands outdoors on a beach cliff

props.synopsis: Liberal sources tell the ABC the "mind-boggling" preselection failure in NSW will motivate the party not to repeat those mistakes in the coming federal election.

title.children: Liberal Party insiders predict 'mind-boggling' preselection failure will see more members sacked

image.altText: Yellow ribbon

props.synopsis: Thousands rally in Israel's largest city demanding Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accept a ceasefire deal, allowing the return of Israeli hostages held in Gaza.

title.children: Large protests staged in Tel Aviv as Israel expresses 'cautious optimism' on Gaza ceasefire

image.altText: Chen Zi Jun works on a laptop on a narrow timber desk inside her flat, with a streaming camera mounted nearby.

props.synopsis: China's strenuous workplace culture demands intense hours with little time for life, prompting many young people to escape the grind — often without another job lined up or any concrete future plans beyond leaving the rat race.

title.children: Chinese companies demand 'work-life integration'. Young people are 'naked quitting' instead

image.altText: GettyImages-2159765795

props.synopsis: The Dogs, the Hawks, and the Blues will all look to solidify their spots in September — but can the Roos, Tigers and Eagles cause upsets to shake up the AFL ladder? Follow live.

title.children: Dogs, Hawks and Blues look to lock up finals as AFL underdogs attempt to create ladder chaos

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: QT: Western Bulldogs lead North Melbourne by 11 points

image.altText: Rebecca Zentveld holding coffee beans in her hands.

props.synopsis: The Australian coffee industry is aiming to get bigger and better. Whether it can or not hinges on access to prime real estate and importing smaller coffee trees.

title.children: Australia is getting ready to make a larger play in the multi-billon dollar coffee industry

image.altText: Luke Nolen riding Black Caviar to victory in 2013.

props.synopsis: Tributes continue to flow for champion Australian racehorse Black Caviar — who was unbeaten in 25 races — following her death on Saturday.

title.children: Black Caviar fondly remembered as an 'absolute demon' with a 'beautiful disposition'

image.altText: A middle aged woman shaking hands with a young school boy. Both are smiling

props.synopsis: The future of public schools will be decided in weeks. Will warring ministers miss the chance to fulfil the promise of the Gonski reforms?

title.children: Weeks remain to negotiate a new public school funding deal. Teachers say the stakes couldn't be higher

image.altText: A group of doctors are protesting and holding banners calling for an end to violence against medical professionals.

props.synopsis: More than 1 million doctors were expected to join the strike, protesting the brutal rape and murder of a female junior doctor in a Kolkata hospital.

title.children: 'Not a one-off incident': Indian doctors strike after rape and murder of female trainee

image.altText: Gloved hands hold a cotton swab towards a teenager's face, which is covered in lotion.

props.synopsis: The World Health Organization once again declares mpox a public health emergency after rolling back an emergency declaration for the virus in mid-2023.

title.children: How did Democratic Republic of the Congo's humanitarian crisis help mpox spiral again?

image.altText: Cameron McEvoy holds the Australian flag with his Olympic gold medal.

props.synopsis: At the crossroads in his career following the Tokyo Olympics in 2021, Australian swimmer Cameron McEvoy chose to follow his instincts. The end result was winning gold at the Paris Games.

title.children: How rock climbing and a chat at an airport hotel sparked Cam McEvoy's rise to Olympic champion

image.altText: An older woman with grey hair and peircing blue eyes smiles while looking into the camera.

props.synopsis: People are living longer, and we can expect to see more people reach 100 in the years to come. But what sort of factors specifically contribute to living to 100?

title.children: We reviewed the health habits of centenarians. These four things could lead to a longer life

props.synopsis: Indira Naidoo reported on Timor-Leste for many years as a young journalist. On her first ever visit to the country, with President Ramos-Horta as her guide, Indira discovers the challenges this young democracy faces and what the future holds.

title.children: Indira Naidoo and the president on a Mini Moke adventure through one of the world's youngest democracies

image.altText: Young woman with long hair and cream jumper standing next to artwork with pale textile

props.synopsis: Emerging artist Kasia Kolikow was born with one hand. She's using art to help her find her place in the world and is one of 22 graduate artists on display at a national exhibition.

title.children: Hatched exhibition helps emerging artists find their place in the world

image.altText: Tony Armstrong standing in front of Syndey Harbour with a giant gold logie

props.synopsis: The Logies are on tonight, so this is your last chance to see who is up for Australian TV's biggest gong before the winners are announced.

title.children: Logies winners list: See all the nominees from Bluey to Boy Swallows Universe

image.altText: Jabez Manaika

props.synopsis: The Solomon Islands might seem like an island paradise but beyond the crystal waters not everyone has always felt like they belong. Locals with disability are working through stigma to forge their own path towards a brighter future.

title.children: Jabez was kicked out of school. Now he's making radio history

image.altText: A group of protesters holding signs demanding the closure of a controversial juvenile detention centre.

props.synopsis: The hearings into the death in custody of a 16-year-old Indigenous boy have revealed some shocking truths, but a lingering question remains for his family and others: What's the point of it all and can it lead to any meaningful change? WARNING: This story contains the name and image of an Indigenous person who has died.

title.children: Months of hearings in the Unit 18 coronial inquest will boil down to one simple question

image.altText: Baker Boy and bandmates perform onstage at Bluesfest 2019

props.synopsis: As major festivals including Bluesfest, Splendour in the Grass and Groovin the Moo announce cancellations in an industry already on shaky ground, music executives, artists and policymakers have gathered in Darwin to help solve the music industry crisis.

title.children: As music festivals falter, the brightest minds in the industry band together to solve the crisis

image.altText: Hard Quiz host Tom Gleeson smirks behind the podium. The Hard Quiz logo is in the top right corner

props.synopsis: Welcome back, I missed you! Just kidding, that never happens. Let's get on with it, it's time to play, HARD!

title.children: Reckon you could outsmart one of my contestants? Prove it

image.altText: An Indonesian guy taking a photo with his rental girlfriend in a photobox.

props.synopsis: Imagine a service where you can hire someone to go on a romantic date, hold your hand during a movie, send flirty texts, and even stay on the phone with you until you drift off to sleep. Here is a look at the growing rent-a-partner industry in Indonesia.

title.children: 'Your dream partner': Inside the booming industry of rental girlfriends and boyfriends

image.altText: A hand stacking casino chips at a roulette table.

props.synopsis: Thailand's stunning beaches, delicious food and unique cultural heritage are already big drawcards for tourists. Soon the country could add roulette, blackjack and pokies to its list of attractions.

title.children: Why Thailand's move to legalise gambling is a risky bet

image.altText: Tasmania Police car with lights on.

props.synopsis: Police say a volunteer firefighter aged in his 60s died on Flinders Island after he was hit by a police vehicle being driven by an on-duty officer.

title.children: 'A tragedy involving two people who worked together': Volunteer firefighter dies after being struck by police vehicle

image.altText: A man in a long sleeved black and white chequered jacket and jeans stands in a paddock of barley.

props.synopsis: Farmers in the Murray-Darling Basin fear proposed mineral sand mines could raise water tables and increase soil salinity, as mining companies plan to pump billions of litres of water per year into mines in Victoria and NSW.

title.children: Mineral sands mining plans spark water concerns in Murray-Darling Basin

image.altText: A generic photograph of an unidentified WA Police officer wearing a high visibility police vest over a blue uniform.

props.synopsis: The three-year-old girl died last week after the car she was travelling in rolled over on an outback dirt road in WA's north.

title.children: Man charged with manslaughter after toddler dies in Pilbara car crash

image.altText: Four people are silhouetted against the backdrop of the moon, which looks massive thanks to a special camera lens

props.synopsis: The night sky will be lit up next week with a bright 'blue' supermoon. Here's what to expect — and why it won't actually have a unique hue.

title.children: Next week will start with a 'blue' supermoon. Here's the best night to see it

image.altText: A large yellow wall in front of two escalators

props.synopsis: The train stations of Sydney's CBD have been little more than grubby pit stops, but those behind the new metro project hope that its gleaming stations with architectural-scale artworks will have commuters looking twice.

title.children: The story behind the art and architecture inside Sydney Metro's new city stations
